Package org.cloudsimplus.traces.azure

Class TracesSimulationManager

java.lang.Object
org.cloudsimplus.traces.azure.TracesSimulationManager
public class TracesSimulationManager extends Object
A class for facilitating the trace-based simulations by keeping all the configuration parameters in a single place. It also provides a set of helper functions for common tasks like creating Vms and Hosts.
Steps to properly run trace-based simulations with this class: 
  (1) Create the TracesSimulationManager and set the configuration parameters 
      with the setter functions
  (2) Create the CloudSim and DatacenterBroker objects
  (3) Initialize TracesSimulationManager by calling initialize(CloudSim, DatacenterBroker)
  (4) Create the data center, i.e., DatacenterSimple, by 
      providing as input the Hosts and the VmAllocationPolicy 
      returned by the getHosts() and getVmAllocationPolicy() functions
  (5) Start the simulation by calling CloudSim.start()
  (6) Save the results by using saveResults()
For a detailed example see class VmPlacementGroupsWithAzureTraces in org.cloudsimplus.examples.traces.vmplacementgroups.

An important aspect of these simulations is that we are only interested in the lifetimes of the VMs and not in the particular Cloudlets that run in them. To control how long the VMs stay alive we follow these steps: 
  (1) We set the MIPS capacity equal to 1 for all the PEs of all 
      hosts. See createHost(long, long, long, long)
  (2) We create only one new Cloudlet for every request. 
      See TracesBatchesManager.createRequest(java.util.List<org.cloudsimplus.traces.azure.VmRecord>)
  (3) We set the Cloudlet's MI parameter equal to the lifetime of 
      the VM in seconds. See TracesBatchesManager.vmAllocationListener(org.cloudsimplus.listeners.VmEventInfo)
  (4) Once the Cloudlets finish their execution we destroy the VMs 
      of the corresponding requests. See TracesBatchesManager.cloudletFinishListener(org.cloudsimplus.listeners.CloudletVmEventInfo)
Alternatively we could build a solution around Cloudlet's function setLifeTime(). feature, which, however, was not available when this solution was built.

For the Pes we use the PeProvisionerSimple while for the Cloudlet we use the CloudletSchedulerSpaceShared.
Since:
CloudSim Plus 7.3.2
Author:
Pavlos Maniotis
See Also:

  • TracesStatisticsManager

  • CloudletSchedulerSpaceShared

      private org.cloudbus.cloudsim.hosts.Host createHost(long cores, long ramMiB, long bwMbps, long storageMiB)
      Creates a hosts with MIPS = 1 for all Pes
      Parameters:
      cores - the number of cores
      ramMiB - the amount of RAM
      bwMbps - the amount of bandwidth
      storageMiB - the amount of storage

    • createVmPlacementGroup

      public VmPlacementGroup createVmPlacementGroup(long numOfVms, long cores, long ramMiB, long bwMbps, long storageMiB, long submissionDelay)
      Creates a VmPlacementGroup with submission delay. All VmPlacementGroups are created as VmPlacementGroupScope.SWITCH, VmPlacementGroupAffinityType.AFFINITY with VmPlacementGroupEnforcement.BEST_EFFORT
      Parameters:
      numOfVms - the number of VMs in the VM placement group
      cores - the number of cores / VM
      ramMiB - the amount of RAM / VM
      bwMbps - the amount of bandwidth / VM
      storageMiB - the amount of storage / VM
      submissionDelay - the submission Delay
      Returns:
      a VmPlacementGroup with submission delay

    • calculateIdealNumOfHosts

      public long calculateIdealNumOfHosts(long numOfVms, long cores, long ramMiB, long bwMbps, long storageMiB)
      Calculates the minimum number of Hosts that can be used to place the VmPlacementGroup.
      Parameters:
      numOfVms - the number of VMs in the VM placement group
      cores - the number of cores / VM
      ramMiB - the amount of RAM / VM
      bwMbps - the amount of bandwidth / VM
      storageMiB - the amount of storage / VM
      Returns:
      the minimum number of Hosts that can be used to place the VmPlacementGroup.
